messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 50 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Achieve Optimal Adversarial Accuracy for Adversarial Deep Learning using Stackelberg GameThis work is partially supported by NSFC grant No.12288201 and NKRDP grant No.2018YFA0704705.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Adversarial deep learning is to train robust DNNs against adversarial attacks, which is one of the major research focuses of deep learning. Game theory has been used to answer some of the basic questions about adversarial deep learning such as the existence of a classifier with optimal robustness and the existence of optimal adversarial samples for a given class of classifiers. In most previous work, adversarial deep learning was formulated as a simultaneous game and the strategy spaces are assumed to be certain probability distributions in order for the Nash equilibrium to exist. But, this assumption is not applicable to the practical situation. In this paper, we give answers to these basic questions for the practical case where the classifiers are DNNs with a given structure, by formulating the adversarial deep learning as sequential games. The existence of Stackelberg equilibria for these games are proved. Furthermore, it is shown that the equilibrium DNN has the largest adversarial accuracy among all DNNs with the same structure, when Carlini-Wagner‚Äôs margin loss is used. Trade-off between robustness and accuracy in adversarial deep learning is also studied from game theoretical aspect. Keywords. Adversarial deep learning, Stackelberg game, optimal robust DNN, universal adversarial attack, adversarial accuracy, trade-off result.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 50 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 50"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Obfuscated Gradients Give a False Sense of Security: Circumventing Defenses to Adversarial Examples",
        "Synthesizing Robust Adversarial Examples",
        "Why Do Deep Convolutional Networks Generalize so Poorly to Small Image Transformations?",
        "The Mathematics of Adversarial Attacks in AI - Why Deep Learning is Unstable Despite the Existence of Stable Neural Networks",
        "Adversarial Example Games",
        "Towards Evaluating the Robustness of Neural Networks",
        "Adversarial Examples are not Easily Detected: Bypassing Ten Detection Methods",
        "Game Theoretical Adversarial Deep Learning With Variational Adversaries",
        "Certified Adversarial Robustness via Randomized Smoothing",
        "The Difficulty of Computing Stable And Accurate Neural Networks: On The Barriers of Deep Learning and Smale‚Äôs 18th Problem",
        "Adversarial Classification",
        "Stability and Perfection of Nash Equilibia",
        "Implicit Learning Dynamics in Stackelberg Games: Equilibria Characterization, Convergence Analysis, and Empirical Study",
        "Game Theory",
        "A Further Generalization of the Kakutani Fixed Point Theorem, with Application to Nash Equilibrium Points",
        "Minimax Theorem for Latent Games or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying about Mixed-Nash and Love Neural Nets",
        "Understanding Black-box Predictions via Influence Functions",
        "Finding Mixed Nash Equilibria of Generative Adversarial Networks",
        "What is Local Optimality in Nonconvex-nonconcave Minimax Optimization?",
        "Game Theory and Machine Learning for Cyber Security",
        "Adversarial Examples in the Physical World",
        "Deep Learning",
        "Fault Injection Attack on Deep Neural Network",
        "Towards Deep Learning Models Resistant to Adversarial Attacks",
        "Mixed Nash Equilibria in the Adversarial Examples Game",
        "On the Number of Linear Regions of Deep Neural Networks",
        "Universal Adversarial Perturbations",
        "Norm-based Capacity Control in Neural Networks",
        "A Game Theoretic Analysis of Additive Adversarial Attacks and Defenses",
        "The Limitations of Deep Learning in Adversarial Settings",
        "Practical Black-box Attacks Against Machine Learning",
        "Randomization Matters: How to Defend Against Strong Adversarial Attacks",
        "Adversarial Risk via Optimal Transport and Optimal Couplings",
        "Beyond Local Nash Equilibria for Adversarial Networks",
        "A Unified Game-Theoretic Interpretation of Adversarial Robustness",
        "Poison Frogs! Targeted Clean-label Poisoning Attacks on Neural Networks",
        "Are Adversarial Examples Inevitable?",
        "Multiagent Systems: Algorithmic, Game Theoretic and Logical Foundations",
        "On the Stackelberg Strategy in Nonzero-sum Games",
        "Intriguing Properties of Neural Networks",
        "Formalizing Generalization and Robustness of Neural Networks to Weight Perturbations",
        "Robustness May Be at Odds With Accuracy",
        "Essential Equilibrium Points of nùëõn-Person Noncooperative Games",
        "Adversarial Attacks and Defenses in Images, Graphs and Text: A Review",
        "A Closer Look at Accuracy vs Robustness",
        "Improve the Robustness and Accuracy of Deep Neural Network with L2,‚àûsubscriptùêø2L_{2,\\infty} Normalization",
        "Adversarial Parameter Attack on Deep Neural Networks",
        "Robust and Information-theoretically Safe Bias Classifier against Adversarial Attacks",
        "Theoretically Principled Trade-off Between Robustness and Accuracy",
        "A survey of Game Theoretic Approach for Adversarial Machine Learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 50 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Achieve Optimal Adversarial Accuracy for Adversarial Deep Learning using Stackelberg GameThis work is partially supported by NSFC grant No.12288201 and NKRDP grant No.2018YFA0704705., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
